Ixodidae and Argasidae Ixodes scapularis http://iscapularis.vectorbase.org/SequenceData/Mitochondria/ 2011-09-16

Ontologies

VectorBase supports four ontologies developed by IMBB with members of the research community. These are available for browsing and download.

There are no updates for this release.

Ontology Version Description
MIRO 1.8 An ontology to describe mosquito populations, methods and mechanisms that are used to identify/monitor insecticide resistance.
TGMA 1.1 An ontology to describe the anatomy of mosquitoes.
TADS 1.2 An ontology to describe the anatomy of ticks.
IDOMAL 1.2 An ontology to describe all aspects of malaria. Clinical data, epidemiological data, biological data concerning vertebrate hosts, vectors and parasites as well as interventions and attempts to control the disease.

Known issues

Other issues resolved with this release:

  • Addressed a GFF upload problem reported by a VectorBase user. GFFs should be supported by the Ensembl genome browsers this release
  • Added GDAV and a community gene comment page to VectorBase tools
  • Streamlined PubMed ID submission, which are now available directly from the Genome Browser
  • Updated the Rhodnius prolixus genome scaffolds with “soft” masked versions for the VectorBase community

Please report any problems to the helpdesk.

Hyperlinks have been removed and URLs may no longer be valid.

Overview

Highlights of the October release of VectorBase (VB-2011-10) include:

  • Several major new microarray experiments added for Anopheles gambiae and Aedes aegypti.
  • Flat file expression downloads and an expression map are now available for Aedes aegypti.

Genomes

No new genomic data has been released or updated.

Fully released genomes, with gene predictions

Glossina morsitansYale GmorY1 - Repeats, RNA-seq (via BAM files) - EST-build genes, SNAP ab initio predictions, MAKER gene predictions.

Expression data

Nine experiments have been added, from five publications:

Circadian rhythm in Anopheles gambiae, heads and bodies in two light regimes (Rund et al., 2011):

  • heads: dark-dark
  • heads: light-dark
  • bodies: dark-dark
  • bodies: light-dark

Adult tissues (Baker et al., 2011) - a.k.a. MozAtlas data (Anopheles gambiae)

Ageing in Anopheles gambiae:

  • Adult male mosquito ageing (Cook & Sinkins, 2010)
  • Adult female mosquito ageing (Cook & Sinkins, 2010)

Two Aedes aegypti insecticide/xenobiotic experiments:

  • Imidacloprid-resistant vs. susceptible larvae and adults (Riaz et al., 2011)
  • Xeniobiotic pre-exposed permethrin-resistant strains (Poupardin et al., 2011)

Legibility of the "x-axis" labels on the expression plots has been improved.

Expression maps

As usual, the Anopheles gambiae expression map has been updated with the new experimental data (now clustering 12k+ genes over 183 experimental conditions).

New for this release is the first Aedes aegypti expression map. It visualises the expression of 13k+ genes over 24 experimental conditions.

Genome browser

The probes for the microarray used in the two Aedes aegypti experiments listed above have been mapped to the genome and can be visualised in Location View by enabling the LIV_AGILENT_8X15K_V1 track.

There are no updates for this release.

Alignments linked to through the "view raw alignment" drop-down in BLAST results may be significantly truncated. Please use the "view raw results" link for details on all alignments. We are working to resolve this issue in time for the next release.

doc.label: Release VB_2011-08
doc.content:
Note, this is legacy information that refers to an older version of the VectorBase website.
Hyperlinks have been removed and URLs may no longer be valid.

Overview

Highlights of the August release of VectorBase (VB-2011-08) include:

  • First announcement of the new population biology resource prototype web interface.
  • Updated Ensembl genome browser (to schema 63).

Genomes

No new genomic data has been released or updated.

Fully released genomes, with gene predictions

Species Assembly Gene set GenBank WGS
Aedes aegypti Liverpool AaegL1 AaegL1.2 AAGE02000000

Glossina morsitansYale GmorY1 - Repeats, RNA-seq (via BAM files) - EST-build genes, SNAP ab initio predictions, MAKER gene predictions.

Population data

We are in the process of consolidating and enhancing VectorBase's population biology resources. We currently have a prototype population sample browser which incorporates insecticide resistance data from IRbase and karyotype and microsatellite data from labs at UCLA and UC Davis. All data and website functionality is subject to change.

Our aim is to handle all types of population data, from classical genetics to high throughput sequencing, from manipulated lab strains to "wild type" field samples. Full integration with the genomic variation data shown in the genome browser is planned. Comments and suggestions are welcome (please email the helpdesk).

Expression data

No new expression data is being released officially in VB-2011-08. However, preliminary access is available to the Anopheles gambiae circadian rhythm dataset recently published by Rund et al. via the Expression Browser Preview site. Example genes with very strong rhythmic expression are timeless and period.

A web site with specialised circadian analysis is available at http://www.nd.edu/~bioclock/

Genome browser

TThe latest version (63) of the Ensembl genome browser software has been installed at VectorBase. The main new features are:

  • Sortable tracks: In the "Region Overview" and "Region in Details", it is now possible to re-order the tracks by dragging them onto a new position.
  • New style pop up menus: the pop up menus that appears when you click on a gene, for example, have been redesigned.
  • Download as CVS: all the tables are downloadable as CVS - check out for the "CVS" icon on the top right corner of the tables.

doc.label: Release VB_2011-06
doc.content:
Note, this is legacy information that refers to an older version of the VectorBase website.
Hyperlinks have been removed and URLs may no longer be valid.

Overview

Highlights of the June release of VectorBase (VB-2011-06) include:

  • Pre-site for Glossina moritans. Features mapped to the genome and preliminary gene sets available (see below).
  • Glossina moritans assembly available for BLAST searching.
  • New microarray data from Christian et al. and Cassone et al.

Genomes

The Glossina morsitans genome is available as pre-site: facilitates the browsing of the genome assembly with repeats and RNA-seq alignments, as well as EST-build genes, ab initio SNAP predictions and MAKER predictions. Please note that these gene predictions are "work in progress" and will not be maintained as such in the final gene set. Full gene predictions will follow in a subsequent VectorBase release.

Fully released genomes, with gene predictions

Species Assembly Gene set GenBank WGS
Aedes aegypti Liverpool AaegL1 AaegL1.2 AAGE02000000
Anopheles gambiae PEST AgamP3 AgamP3.6 AAAB01000000
Culex quinquefasciatus JHB CpipJ1 CpipJ1.2 AAWU01000000
Ixodes scapularis Wikel IscaW1 IscaW1.1 ABJB01000000
Pediculus humanus USDA PhumU1 PhumU1.2 AAZO01000000

Pre-released genomes, with mapped data but no gene predictions

Species Assembly GenBank WGS Data available
Anopheles gambiae M AgamM1 ABKP00000000 Repeats, ESTs
Anopheles gambiae S AgamS1 ABKQ00000000 Repeats, ESTs
Rhodnius prolixus CDC RproC1 ACPB00000000 Repeats, ESTs, RNA-seq and protein similarities - GenScan ab initio predictions and EST-build genes.
Glossina morsitansYale GmorY1 - Repeats, RNA-seq (via BAM files) - EST-build genes, SNAP ab initio predictions, MAKER gene predictions.

Expression data

Data from two recent publications have been added to the Expression Browser:

PublicationExpression Browser linkSpeciesDescription
Christian et al., Pesticide Biochemistry and Physiology Volume 99, Issue 2 Anopheles funestus pyrethroid resistant vs. susceptible (Christian et al., 2010) Anopheles funestus (using an Anopheles gambiae array) Gene expression differences between a pyrethroid resistant strain (FUMOZ-R) of Anopheles funestus from Mozambique and a susceptible strain (FANG) of the same species from Angola were measured using the "Detox" chip designed for Anopheles gambiae, which features mostly detoxification genes. Adult females and males have been assayed separately.
Cassone et al., Mol Ecol. 2011 May 3 Response to thermal stress in 2La and 2L+(a) karyotype mosquitoes (Cassone et al., 2011) Anopheles gambiae Anopheles gambiae larvae with or without the 2La chromosomal inversion were assayed for gene expression differences in the presence or absence of thermal stress at three time points.

The resource now contains 42 experiments, assaying 120 experimental conditions over three species.

The Expression BioMart and (Anopheles gambiae) Expression Map have been updated with the new data. Note that the Expression Map analysis now excludes experimental conditions with fewer than 1000 assayed genes and genes with fewer than 10 assayed conditions.

As always, all microarray designs present in the Expression Browser are available as "Probe feature" tracks in the Genome Browser (they are not switched on by default, however).

Genome browser

The latest version (62) of the Ensembl genome browser software has been installed at VectorBase. This version features more informative and functional track labels (mouse-over to find out more) when in Location View.

Download data

New Glossina morsitans genome data is now available for download. Some naming confusions have been remedied throughout the downloads section.

Additionally, RNAseq transcriptome FASTA file downloads for nine Anopheline species have been made available via their annotation browser homepages which are linked from the newly re-vamped Additional Organisms page

doc.label: Release VB_2011-04
doc.content:
Note, this is legacy information that refers to an older version of the VectorBase website.
Hyperlinks have been removed and URLs may no longer be valid.

Overview

Highlights of the April release of VectorBase (VB-2011-04) include:

  • New microarray expression data for Culex quinquefasciatus and Aedes aegypti
  • Updated mass spec. peptides for Anopheles gambiae available via DAS and simple browsing interface
  • Anopheles funestus RNAseq contigs available for BLAST and browsing and search
  • GTF file format for use in tophat/cufflinks analysis of RNA-seq data available for download from all species.

Genomes

Fully released genomes, with gene predictions

Anopheles gambiae S AgamS1 ABKQ00000000 Repeats, ESTs
Rhodnius prolixus CDC RproC1 ACPB00000000 Repeats, ESTs, RNA-seq and protein similarities - GenScan ab initio predictions and EST-build genes.

Expression data

Three microarray experiments have been added, from two publications:

  • Permethrin resistant Culex quinquefasciatus strain comparison (Komagata et al., 2010)
  • Blood meal timecourse in Aedes aegypti (Dissanayake et al., 2010)
  • Male vs. female comparison in Aedes aegypti(Dissanayake et al., 2010)

The Aedes aegypti SINV infection experiment has been removed due to data processing issues. However, raw and processed data files for this experiment are available at ArrayExpress, and its array probes will remain available in VectorBase's genome browser.

The Expression Biomart has been updated to reflect the changes and additions. The Anopheles gambiae Expression Map and download files remain unchanged (no new data for this organism this release).

Genome browser

An updated Anopheles gambiae mass spectrometry proteomics dataset courtesy of the Pandey lab (JHU) has been incorporated into the genome browser. There were no upgrades to the genome browser software for this release. We encourage you to report any issues to the VectorBase helpdesk.

Download area

  • Update of all EST transcriptome files to ENA release 106 (Dec 2010). Sequences are available both as raw fasta and clipped to remove poly A/T runs.
  • Minor corrections to the fasta headers for the proteome and transcriptome files for all species.
  • Corrections to better handle UTR annotations in GFF3 files for all species.
  • First release of GTF files suitable for use in tophat/cufflinks analysis for all species.

Mitochondrial gene summaries for VectorBase genera

Mitochondrial sequences for genus Anopheles, genus Aedes, family Ixodidae, family Argasidase, genus Culex from GenBank (as of 2011-03-23) have been BLASTed against the corresponding reference mitochondrial genome, and the results have been grouped by matching genes.

Tools

The BLAST user interface has been beautified via HTML5 and is visible with Chrome, Safari, and the newest version of Firefox. As well as adding Rhodnius prolixus data to the BLAST facility at VectorBase, we have made it easier to search the eight Anopheline RNAseq datasets. Simply select "Other organisms" in the main BLAST menu. Results are now linked through to sequence report pages.

Known issues

Please check the VectorBase Twitter page for news on these few remaining issues.

Genome browser: Gene & Transcript pages for GenScan predictions

The Gene and Transcript pages for the GenScan predictions are not activated. This is due to the way the GenScan data are stored in the database. This issue has been addressed and will be corrected for next release.

CV Search

The Controlled Vocabulary (CV) search pages are currently not working. Selecting an ontology to browse will not initiate a session. We are working on this issue and hope to re-instate the browser as soon as possible.

Please report any problems to the helpdesk.

doc.label: Release VB_2011-02
doc.content:
Note, this is legacy information that refers to an older version of the VectorBase website.
Hyperlinks have been removed and URLs may no longer be valid.

Overview

Highlights of the February release of VectorBase (VB-2011-02) include:

  • Pre-site for Rhodnius prolixus. Facilitates the browsing of the genome assembly with repeats, ESTs, RNA-seq and proteins alignments. GenScan ab-initio predictions as well as EST-build genes are presented. Please note that these gene predictions are "work in progress" and will not be maintained as such in the final gene set. Full gene predictions will follow in a subsequent VectorBase release.
  • Rhodnius prolixus assembly available for BLAST searching.
  • Improved access to Anopheline RNAseq datasets via BLAST (see Tools below).
  • New database cross-reference sources for Anopheles gambiae and Aedes aegypti including AnoXcel data and PubMed references.

Expression data

There is no new data for this release. However, two small cosmetic changes have been made to the Expression Browser web interface:

  • Where genes are associated with a large number of reporters (a.k.a. probes), we now make more efficient use of screen space so you don't have to scroll so much.
  • Fold-changes are reported in the summaries of "Neighbour t-tests". Previously just the direction (up or down) was reported.

A new search facility is being developed to allow search based on reporters' text expression summaries. Interested users may test the new index at the preview site (example query: permethrin expression). Note: major changes are likely as we improve the utility of this feature. We welcome your feedback on this and any other search-related issues at VectorBase.

Genome browser

There were no upgrades to the genome browser software for this release. Most teething problems associated with the previous release have been fixed, however. We encourage you to report any other issues to the VectorBase helpdesk.

doc.label: Release VB-2012-12
doc.content:
Overview

As part of a ongoing development, and feedback from multiple constituents, we have upgraded the VectorBase site. The prior version of the website is available at https://classic.vectorbase.org and still has some legacy data of interest. To help you get acclimated with the new site, here are six specific changes:

  • We have redesigned the homepage to highlight data, tools and resources, FAQs and community interactions. We also anticipate user-focused customization (e.g., accessing previous analyses) in later versions of this site.
  • The BLAST tool has been improved based on prior feedback and is available under the “Tools” tab.
  • Computing resources increased by 100% for BLAST, ClustalW, and HMMER jobs.
  • The search box in the upper right corner of all VectorBase pages can access a new unified search framework. Data is faceted and queries can be filterable by species or type. For more information follow this link and found the Search tutorial.
  • We have extended the organisms page. This has allowed us to group genomes in a scalable manner while also highlighting and archiving strain, assembly and gene build history.
  • The old help pages/wiki have been reallocated into new content under “Help” and “Community” tabs to consolidate these important documents into a single site and to facilitate search access.
You can also take a tour of the new site

Other highlights of the December release of VectorBase (VB-2012-12) include:

  • First release of dengue ontology (IDODEN)
  • Anopheles darlingi included in VectorBase compara & mart resources
  • An update to gene symbols and synonyms for mosquito species adding or modifying 830 loci
We are interested in feedback about these changes using the Contact Us page or mail the the helpdesk.

IDOMAL 1.2.4 An ontology to describe all aspects of malaria. Clinical data, epidemiological data, biological data concerning vertebrate hosts, vectors and parasites as well as interventions and attempts to control the disease.
MIRO 2.0 An ontology to describe mosquito populations, methods and mechanisms that are used to identify/monitor insecticide resistance.

TGMA 1.10 An ontology to describe the anatomy of mosquitoes.

Ontology browser

The Controlled Vocabulary/Ontology browser has been upgraded. Most noteworthy changes:

  • it is now possible to search for terms using synonyms
  • Term synonyms are now listed along with the rest of the term's details
  • OBO flat files can be downloaded by using the links on the main page of the CV browser

Known issues

Biomart filtering on variation type is not working, this will be addressed for the next release.

Please report any problems to the helpdesk.

doc.label: Notes on the scaffolds of the Anopheles gambiae PEST whole genome shotgun assembly
How to find a triad of BACs in situ images, divisions and photomaps?
doc.content:
• Go to your area of interest in the genome browser, e.g., 2L:46523702-46773701

  • Identify your BAC clone name of interest using the track called “BAC map” displayed as bright green, e.g., 27D19

    (To activate this track go to the tutorial called "Browsing genomes: Visualizing and adding tracks" and follow instructions on slide #11)

    Hint: the track called “BACs” and displayed in gray are in silico (i.e. computationally) aligned to chromosomes and in consequence will not have images associated.

  • Go to the top of the page and type your queries in the search box, e.g., 27D19* (you get in situ image and photomap); *27D* (you get the division image)

    Hint:in order for these queries to work you have to include the asterisk (*) as shown in the examples above. For more information about how to use asterisk for search follow this link and on look for slide 7 and 8 of the tutorial

For more information about all the BAC images archived at VectoBase please contact Dr. Maria V. Sharakhova (msharakh@vt.edu).

Biomphalaria glabrata
doc.content: Biomphalaria glabrata, a neotropical snail, is one of several aquatic snail species that serve as obligate intermediate hosts for flatworm parasites of the genus Schistosoma, causative pathogens of schistosomiasis. This debilitating infectious disease afflicts over 200 million people globally. Patently infected B. glabrata snails shed and seed their aquatic environment with numerous free-swimming cercariae, the stage of Schistosoma mansoni that is infective for humans. Water contact leads to infection because cercariae can actively penetrate human skin. Inside the human host, schistosome parasites mature and reproduce sexually. Parasite eggs are released in the feces and/or urine of infected humans. Parasite larvae called miracidia hatch from the eggs and swim to locate and infect B. glabrata for completion of the S. mansoni life cycle.

doc.label: Obtaining the genome sequence of the mollusc Biomphalaria glabrata: a major intermediate host for the parasite causing human schistosomiasis.
doc.content:
Freshwater snails of the genus Biomphalaria are important intermediate snail hosts for the widespread 
transmission of schistosomiasis in humans. This chronic and debilitating disease remains one of the 
most intractable public health concerns in 74 developing countries, infecting more than 200 million
people. Prevalence of schistosomiasis is difficult to estimate, but according to the World Health 
Organization more than 600 million people are currently at risk for infection with either one or more of 
the three medically important schistosome species,  Schistosoma mansoni, Schistosoma japonicum and 
Schistosoma haematobium (WHO Expert Committee, 1993). Although control measures involving the 
combined use of molluscicides and mass chemotherapy have been effective in slowing the spread of the 
disease, long-term prevention of schistosomiasis has been difficult to achieve because of re-infection in 
the human population following chemotherapy. Ideally, a protective vaccine against the parasite will be 
the best method to combat the spread of this disease, but efforts to develop a vaccine have proven to be 
challenging (Bergquist, 1998). Thus, with neither a vaccine nor a thorough understanding of the 
parasite/host interaction at both the human and snail stages of the parasite’s life cycle, we continue to 
make less than optimal progress in reducing transmission of schistosomiasis around the world. Added to 
this current situation is the decline in public health measures in several affected countries due to 
poverty, a rise in civil wars, and the construction of dams and new irrigation schemes in areas at most 
risk for schistosomiasis

doc.label: Submit
doc.content: If you've determined the transcript sequence of a specific gene of interest, you can submit that data to VectorBase Community Annotation Portal (CAP). After submission, your transcript sequence will be reviewed by a VectorBase curator and a gene model will be created from your submitted transcript. That model will be displayed in the VectorBase Genome Browser "Manual Annotation" DAS Track until incoporation into the organism's official gene build. If you want to discuss any issues raised in this tutorial then please contact the help desk.

2013 Mosquito Kolymbari meeting
doc.content:
We are pleased to announce the opening of registrations for the 2013 Mosquito Kolymbari meeting that will take place in Kolymbari, Crete, Greece on July 15-19, 2013. The call will close on March 15. As in previous years, places will be limited, therefore we may not be able to accept all the applications. Applications will be reviewed by the organising committee both on the basis of abstracts and with the aim to ensure broad participation. All the applicants will be informed about the success of their application soon after the deadline.

Please find the link to the webpage and registration: http://events.embo.org/13-mosquito.

Note the following changes compared to previous years:

  • There are 9 thematic sessions. When you register, you will be requested to indicate 2 sessions to which your paper may fit best.
  • Both short talks and posters are accepted.

Also note that there will be a number of travel fellowships and reduced registration fees for scientists from Low/Middle Income and Disease Endemic Countries (DECs) as well as for early stage researchers (e.g. PhD students).

Please propagate this announcement and encourage your colleagues in DECs and the best of your students to apply.

Best wishes, The organising committee: George Christophides (main organiser) Anthony James (main organiser) John Vontas (main organiser) Abdoulaye Diabate Barry Beaty Alessandra della Torre Catherine Hill Didier Fontenille Humberto Lanz Mendoza Jake Tu Tom Scott Luna Kamau Pedro de Oliveira Robert Sinden Maureen Coetzee Nora Besansky Janet Hemingway Yeya Toure John Vontas

doc.label: 7th Annual Arthropod Genomics Symposium
doc.content:
• VectorBase Workshop: June 12-June 13, 2013.
  • AGS: June 13-June 15, 2013.

Follow this link for more details:

7th Annual Arthropod Genomics Symposium (AGS)

VectorBase Hands-on Workshop

McKenna Hall, University of Notre Dame, Notre Dame, IN (Follow this link for a campus map)

Instructors

Gloria I. Giraldo-Calderón (University of Notre Dame)

Andrew Sheehan (University of Notre Dame)

Dan Lawson (European Molecular Biology Laboratory, EMBL - European Bioinformatics Institute, EBI)

Robert M. Waterhouse (University of Geneva Medical School - Massachusetts Institute of Technology, MIT)

About the VectorBase Hands-on Workshop

The goal of the workshop is to present a brief overview of the (NEW) VectorBase website and offer a training and data analysis opportunity to users. This two-day event will comprise a mixture of lectures and hands-on practical sessions where users can discuss their own data sets/problems with the instructors and fellow attendees. The instructors will be vector bioinformaticians and biologists.

Computer and Internet Access

The training room will not provide computers for participants. You are encouraged to bring your own laptop to use. Arrive early in order to get access to the Internet.

Registration

Seating is limited to 30 people. Please register early to ensure a seat. To register please follow this link . After you register please contact Gloria Giraldo-Calderon at ggiraldo@nd.edu and include the following in your email: your 1) research interest detailing your aims, hypotheses, research questions, gene or genes of interest; 2) data type you work with or would like to work with, e.g. RNA-seq, re-sequencing, SNP calls, insecticide resistance data; 3) data status, e.g. raw, processed or ready for submission and; 4) up to three specific questions about VectorBase that would help you with your research (300 words maximum).

Agenda

Wednesday, June 12, 2013, 1:00 – 5:00 pm

1:00 – 1:30 pm: VectorBase (NEW) website navigation

1:30 – 3:00 pm: Finding, visualizing and exporting data (tutorial and exercises)

  • Available data types: VectorBase data and external data sets
  • Search
  • BioMart

3:00 – 3:30 pm: Beak

3:30 – 5:00 pm: Poster session (5 or 10 min presentation from each participant)

Thursday, June 13, 2013, 8:30 am – 5:00 pm

8:30 am – 10:00 am: Finding, visualizing and uploading data (tutorial and exercises)

  • Browsing genomes: visualizing and adding tracks
  • Ontology Browser
  • Insecticide resistance database
  • Population biology browser (beta)

10:00 – 10:30 pm : Break

10:30 – 12:00 pm: Be a VectorBase “power user”

  • How to make the best use of your data, VectorBase data, tools and resources to analyze and publish your research?
  • Hands on session with attendees’ datasets.
  • Opportunity to interact with other VectorBase bioinformaticians and biologists using conference call.

12:00 - 1:00 pm: Lunch

1:00 - 2:00 pm: Invited speaker: Dr. William Gelbart (FlyBase & Harvard University), Mining FlyBase for Gene Function.

2:00 – 3:00 pm: Annotation of vector genomes at VectorBase (tutorial)

3:00 - 3:30 pm: Break

3:30 - 5:00 pm: How to contribute to VectorBase and get community visibility for your research work? (tutorial and exercises)

  • Using HMMER versus BLAST to find homologs
  • Curate and submit genes
  • Link genes to publications
  • Add (submit) transcript or protein data

NOTE:

You are strongly encouraged to bring your own data for all the sessions to make the best out of the hands-on sessions of each of the workshop topics.

doc.label: VectorBase Scientific User Group
doc.content:
The main goal of VectorBase is to be the primary source of bioinformatic resources for the vector community. However, to accomplish this goal we need your help. Next year we will start a Scientific User Group which will meet by conference call every two months, following the VectorBase release schedule. We expect to have a maximum size 15 people and may create multiple groups or meet more frequently based on research interest.

Time investment: Approximately 1 hour every two months

Benefits and expectations:

  • Learn about new "Data" and new "Tools and Resources" and provide your feedback
  • Suggest new features and helping testing them
  • Provide input on outreach plans and opportunities

If you are interested please contact us with your name, institution name and email address.

doc.label: Array Express Submission
doc.content:
Contents

  • 1 Prerequisites
  • 2 Step 1: Deposit array design at ArrayExpress
  • 3 Step 2: Finalize sample annotations and experimental factors
  • 4 Step 3: Create a BASE experiment
  • 5 Step 4: Prepare protocols
  • 6 Step 5: Final data matrix
  • 7 Step 6: Authorize submission

Prerequisites

Your array design and expression data must already be loaded into VectorBase BASE.

Step 1: Deposit array design at ArrayExpress

Follow this link to submit your array design to ArrayExpress, where you will require the following:

  1. An ADF file [1].
    • You can create ADF files from several array design formats using a tool [2] at the EBI (make sure you use the same array design which was submitted to VectorBase).
    • Do not spend time producing elaborate database annotations for your ADF file. You only need one column with the heading "Reporter BioSequence DatabaseEntry [vectorbase_reporterid]" which should simply contain Reporter Identifiers.
    • You do need to spend some time providing the correct information for the following columns in the ADF file (see [3] for more information), unless you already provided us with this information during array layout submission.
    • Reporter BioSequence Type as one of
      • cDNA_clone
      • ds_oligo
      • genomic_DNA
      • PCR_amplicon
      • ss_oligo
    • Reporter BioSequence Polymer Type as one of
      • DNA
      • RNA
      • Protein
    • Reporter Group [role] as one of
      • Experimental
      • Control
    • Reporter Control Type as one of
      • control_biosequence
      • control_buffer
      • control_empty
      • control_genomic_DNA
      • control_label
      • control_reporter_size
      • control_spike_calibration
      • control_unknown_type
  2. Protocol text for your array design and manufacture

Make a note of the ArrayExpress accession number assigned to your array design.

Step 2: Finalize sample annotations and experimental factors

Your sample annotations in BASE should follow the MGED ontology [4] if at all possible. You may need to email us to provide new sample annotation types and options for them. Note that there is a bulk sample annotation facility in BASE.

Make a note of which sample annotations are experimental factors (i.e. the conditions you tested in the experiment).

Step 3: Create a BASE experiment

If you haven't done this already, create an experiment (under the Analyze data→Experiments menu item) and add all the relevant raw data sets to this experiment (using the Analyze data→Raw data sets menu item).

Fill in as much information as possible in the Experiment's info tab. The description text should describe the whole experiment (this will go into ArrayExpress).

Step 4: Prepare protocols

If your protocols are not already in ArrayExpress, write a detailed paragraph to explain each of the following steps: grow, treatment, extraction, labeling, hybridization, scanning, image_analysis.

If your protocols are already in ArrayExpress, make a note of their accession numbers.

Step 5: Final data matrix

To be fully MIAME compliant, ArrayExpress require the submission of processed data which you have refered to in your publication - this is usually filtered (no bad data), normalised and averaged over replicates. See this page for more details of the simple file format used.

Please also write a short piece of protocol text describing the data processing you performed.

Step 6: Authorize submission

Send us an email containing all the information requested above (that is not already in BASE) and we will submit your experiment to ArrayExpress using the TAB2MAGE program.

Why do VectorBase gene IDs change? (finding missing gene IDs)
doc.content:
Change is inevitable. As gene predictions are improved based on new evidence some will have a modified exon structure, new predictions will be created, old ones will be deleted, some will be split into multiple separate predictions and some will be merged together into a single new prediction. During this process the annotation identifiers can change. So how can you find out about these changes and how do you go about finding the new IDs for your genes? Firstly lets deal with what kind of identifiers may be used for a given locus:
  • A gene symbol, e.g. CPLCW5. These are assigned by the community and used as the common name for a locus. This name should be stable and maintained between releases. There are times when the name can change but that will not be initiated by us. We will usually keep the old name as a synonym in cases where genes are renumbered of renamed.
  • An annotation ID e.g. AGAP028126. These are defined during the annotation process and form the basic identifier for the locus onto which all other information is associated. So external database references, or citations will be associated with the AGAP identifier and not with the symbol.
  • Updates to the annotation from the community via the Community Annotation Portal (CAP) are given a separate identifier using the same species/strain prefix but a different set of numeric ordinal (AGAP8nnnnn in the case of Anopheles gambiae). These identifiers will be subsumed into the canonical set of AGAPxxxxxx identifiers when a gene set update happens at release. Note: A locus can have multiple CAP submissions from the community which will show up with different IDs for the community (CAP gene) annotations.

So an example.

"Why when I search for CPLCW5, I get two identifiers: AGAP028126 and AGAP820007. This gene used to be called AGAP008464."

This result shows the annotation ID AGAP028126 and the curation CAP ID AGAP820007. When the updated gene prediction was integrated into the latest geneset the ID was changed from AGAP008464 to AGAP028126 as a consequence of the modification to the predicted exon structure. The gene symbol CPLCW5 has been maintained.

Notification of updated geneset for your species can be found via news items and in the release notes.

For a visualization of both the current canonical and pending new gene models you can go to the genome browser and activate the track called "Community Annotation" under the category "Additional Annotations". For information on how to do it follow this link to the tutorial called "Browsing genomes: Visualizing and adding tracks", and follow slides 1 to 10 using gene CPLCW5. Zoom out to 1.25 kb and left click on both gene tracks for a better perspective of the differences.

Lists of identifier changes are presented with each gene set page, here is the latest Culex quinquefasciatus one as an example.

  • Anopheles gambiae gene set AgamP3.3 (year 2006), 3.4 (2007), 3.5 (2009), 3.6 (2010) and 3.7 (2012)
  • Aedes aegypti gene set AaegL1.1 (year 2006), 1.2 (2009) and 1.3 (2012)
  • Ixodes scapularis gene set IscaW1.1 (year 2008) and 1.2 (2012)
  • Culex quinquefascitus gene set CpipJ1.1 (year 2008), 1.2 (2008) and 1.3 (2012)
  • Pediculus humanus gene set PhumU1.1 (year 2008) and 1.2 (2009)

"How can I cite a specific gene set on my thesis/paper?"

Citation information is available here in the FAQ called called "How to cite VectorBase".

If you type your "old" gene ID on VectorBase search box, the results page should give you the "current" and/or "new" gene IDs. If it does not behave like that please let us now sending an email to info@vectorbase.org . You could also find your gene using blast or type the genomic coordinates, i.e., supercontig and base pair range on the genome browser.

doc.label: Aedes aegypti larvae susceptible to Bti toxin (PMID:22115744)
doc.content: The control of mosquitoes transmitting infectious diseases relies mainly on the use of chemical insecticides. However, resistance to most chemical insecticides threatens mosquito control programs. In this context, the spraying of toxins produced by the bacteria Bacillus thuringiensis subsp. israelensis (Bti) in larval habitats represents an alternative to chemical insecticides and is now widely used for mosquito control. Recent studies suggest that resistance of mosquitoes to Bti toxin may occur locally but mechanisms have not been characterized so far. In the present study, we investigated gene transcription level variations associated with Bti toxin resistance in the mosquito Aedes aegypti using a next-generation sequencing approach. More than 6 million short cDNA tags were sequenced from larvae of two strains sharing the same genetic background: a Bti toxins-resistant strain and a susceptible strain. These cDNA tags were mapped with a high coverage (308 reads per position in average) to more than 6000 genes of Ae. aegypti genome and used to quantify and compare the transcription level of these genes between the two mosquito strains. Among them, 86 genes were significantly differentially transcribed more than 4-fold in the Bti toxins resistant strain comparatively to the susceptible strain. These included gene families previously associated with Bti toxins resistance such as serine proteases, alkaline phosphatase and alpha-amylase. Materials & Methods Aedes aegypti, laboratory strain Bora-Bora susceptible to insecticides, fourth stage 5 days-old larvae of mixed sexes, grown in standard insectary conditions, total RNA isolated from 3 batches of 30 fresh larvae. Other Activation URL is https://www.vectorbase.org/Aedes_aegypti/Location/View?db=core;r=supercont1.406:278498-280429;contigviewbottom=ERP000065_Bti_toxin_resistant=histogram

doc.label: Release VB-2013-02
doc.content:
Overview

We are pleased to announce the February release of VectorBase (VB-2013-02). Highlights of this release include:
  • New gene pinboard and annotation export features in Expression Maps
  • Ensembl genome browser updated to e! 69
  • New version of IDODEN ontology (Dengue)
  • Improved search results for expression and population biology samples
  • Added an ability to download mtDNA sequences by selecting them (based on user feedback)
  • BAC hybridization (Maria V. Sharakhova) and AnoXcel (Jose Ribero) searches from classic site now on new site in beta form
  • Over 100 new gene symbols were incorporated (especially for Ixodes scapularis<\em>)
  • Mitochondrial and CV Browser data updated
  • New organism page: Biomphalaria glabrata
  • Stable ID tracking for recent Aedes, Culex and Ixodes genesets
  • Correction of some stable IDs for Aedes, Culex and Ixodes genesets, old IDs are tracked
  • Nine new tutorials

Genomes

Released genomes, with gene predictions

Species Assembly Gene set GenBank WGS
Aedes aegypti Liverpool AaegL1 AaegL1.3 AAGE02000000
Anopheles darlingi Coari AdarC1 AdarC1.0 ADMH00000000
Anopheles gambiae PEST AgamP3 AgamP3.7 AAAB01000000
Culex quinquefasciatus JHB CpipJ1 CpipJ1.3 AAWU01000000
Ixodes scapularis Wikel IscaW1 IscaW1.2 ABJB01000000
Pediculus humanus USDA PhumU1 PhumU1.2 AAZO01000000
Pre-released genomes, with mapped data and gene predictions
Rhodnius prolixus CDC RproC1 RproC1.0ACPB00000000
Glossina morsitans Yale GmorY1 GmorY1.0 
Anopheles stephensi Indian Wild Type AsteI1 AsteI1.0  

Pre-released genomes, with mapped data but no gene predictions

Species Assembly GenBank WGS Project Data available
Anopheles gambiae MAgamM1 ABKP00000000 Repeats, ESTs
Anopheles gambiae S AgamS1 ABKQ00000000 Repeats, ESTs
Lutzomyia longipalpis Jacobina LlonJ1AJWK00000000 Repeats, SNAP, ESTs
Phlebotomus papatasi IsraelPpapI1 AJVK00000000 Repeats, SNAP, ESTs

Variation Data

No new data for this release.

Expression Data

There is no new microarray expression data for this release, however the Expression Map interface has a new feature. It is now possible to export gene annotation information for the genes in one or more expression cluster with a few clicks of your mouse. Look for the "save gene IDs to pinboard" button in the cluster info popup windows.

Mitochondrial gene summaries for VectorBase genera

Links to Mitochondrial data for the 4 main genera are presented below for convenience.

Genus/generaReference speciesMitochondrial gene resourceLast updated
Aedes Aedes aegypti Aedine mitochondrial genes2013-02-01
Anopheles Anopheles gambiae Anopheline mitochondrial genes2013-02-01
Culex Culex quinquefasciatus Culicine mitochondrial genes2013-02-01
Ixodidae and Argasidae Ixodes scapularis Ixodida mitochondrial genes2013-02-01

Ontologies

VectorBase supports seven ontologies developed by IMBB with members of the research community. These are available for browsing and download.

Ontology Version Description
GAZ 1.512 A controlled vocabulary of geographic locations.
GO 1.1437 The gene ontology.
IDODEN 0.2 Beta release of an an ontology that describes all aspects of Dengue. Clinical data, epidemiological data, biological data concerning vertebrate hosts, vectors and viruses as well as interventions and attempts to control the disease.
IDOMAL 1.2.5 An ontology to describe all aspects of malaria. Clinical data, epidemiological data, biological data concerning vertebrate hosts, vectors and parasites as well as interventions and attempts to control the disease.
MIRO 2.0 An ontology to describe mosquito populations, methods and mechanisms that are used to identify/monitor insecticide resistance.
TADS 1.21 An ontology to describe the anatomy of ticks.
TGMA 1.10 An ontology to describe the anatomy of mosquitoes.

Known issues

Biomart filtering on variation type is not working, this will be addressed for the next release.

Please report any problems to the helpdesk.

doc.label: BB02
doc.content: Biomphalaria glabrata snails were collected by Omar dos Santos Carvalho (CPRR/Fiocruz) in the south east of Brazil (19o59' S 44o02' W), Belo Horizonte, district of Barreiro. Morphology-based species identification was confirmed by PCR_RFLP; 16S rDNA, NADH dehydrogenase 1 sequences (AY737280, AY737281). Lab-reared offspring of the wild caught snails proved susceptible to multiple strains of Schistosoma mansoni. BB02 snails are maintained as inbred lines at several research groups. A BAC library is available for this strain from the Arizona Genomics Institute (Tucson AZ, USA). Genomic DNA was extracted from whole body soft tissues minus the reproductive organs of adult BB02 snails (Coen Adema, UNM) and applied for genome sequencing at The Genomics Institute (TGI), Washington University, St Louis MO.

doc.label: Release VB-2013-04
doc.content:
Overview

We are pleased to announce the April release of VectorBase (VB-2013-04). Highlights of this release include:
  • Release genesets for Glossina morsitans and Rhodnius prolixus
  • Pre-sites including MAKER based gene predictions for Lutzomyia longipalpis, Phlebotomus papatasi & Biomphalaria glabrata
  • Nine Anopheline genome assemblies added for BLAST searching and download from the Anopheles Genomes Cluster
  • Pathway information from the KEGG database added for mosquito, tick and lice species.
  • Two new microarray expression experiments have been curated
  • An improved and searchable glossary (in the 'General' search category)

Genomes

Released genomes, with gene predictions

Species Assembly Gene set GenBank WGS
Aedes aegypti Liverpool AaegL1 AaegL1.3 AAGE02000000
Anopheles darlingi Coari AdarC1 AdarC1.0 ADMH00000000
Anopheles gambiae PEST AgamP3 AgamP3.7 AAAB01000000
Culex quinquefasciatus JHB CpipJ1 CpipJ1.3 AAWU01000000
Ixodes scapularis Wikel IscaW1 IscaW1.2 ABJB01000000
Pediculus humanus USDA PhumU1 PhumU1.2 AAZO01000000
Rhodnius prolixus CDC RproC1 RproC1.1ACPB00000000
Glossina morsitans Yale GmorY1 GmorY1.1 
Pre-released genomes, with mapped data and gene predictions
Anopheles stephensi Indian Wild Type AsteI1 AsteI1.0  
Lutzomyia longipalpis Jacobina LlonJ1LlonJ1.0  
Phlebotomus papatasi IsraelPpapI1 PpapI1.0  
Biomphalaria glabrata BB02 BglaB1 BglaB1.0  

Pre-released genomes, with mapped data but no gene predictions

Species Assembly GenBank WGS Project Data available
Anopheles gambiae MAgamM1 ABKP00000000 Repeats, ESTs
Anopheles gambiae S AgamS1 ABKQ00000000 Repeats, ESTs

Variation Data

No new data for this release.

Expression Data

Two new experiments have been added to the Expression Browser, Maps, BioMart and flat file downloads:

  • Plasmodium berghei infected vs. uninfected (Zhao et al., 2012)
  • Blood fed vs. sugar fed (Spillings et al., 2013)
Several experiments were wrongly cited (to Marinotti et al., 2005) these have been corrected (Marinotti et al., 2006). The naming of two arrays (OXFORD Aedes aegypti AGILENT 44k v1 and OXFORD Anopheles gambiae Agilent 44k v1) have been standardised to correct some case inconsistencies. In addition, a small cosmetic change has been made to gene expression summary pages to provide cleaner links to the genome browser and expression maps.

Mitochondrial gene summaries for VectorBase genera

Links to Mitochondrial data for the 4 main genera are presented below for convenience.

Genus/generaReference speciesMitochondrial gene resourceLast updated
Aedes Aedes aegypti Aedine mitochondrial genes2013-03-19
Anopheles Anopheles gambiae Anopheline mitochondrial genes2013-03-19
Culex Culex quinquefasciatus Culicine mitochondrial genes2013-03-19
Ixodidae and Argasidae Ixodes scapularis Ixodida mitochondrial genes2013-03-19

Ontologies

Release highlight: Added Aedes images to the mosquito anatomy ontology

VectorBase supports seven ontologies developed by IMBB with members of the research community. These are available for browsing and download.

Ontology Version Description
GAZ 1.512 A controlled vocabulary of geographic locations.
GO 2013-04-02 The gene ontology.
IDODEN 0.3 Beta release of an an ontology that describes all aspects of Dengue. Clinical data, epidemiological data, biological data concerning vertebrate hosts, vectors and viruses as well as interventions and attempts to control the disease.
IDOMAL 1.2.6 An ontology to describe all aspects of malaria. Clinical data, epidemiological data, biological data concerning vertebrate hosts, vectors and parasites as well as interventions and attempts to control the disease.
MIRO 2.0 An ontology to describe mosquito populations, methods and mechanisms that are used to identify/monitor insecticide resistance.
TADS 1.21 An ontology to describe the anatomy of ticks.
TGMA 1.11 An ontology to describe the anatomy of mosquitoes.

Known issues

Add known issues here.

  • BioMart will be updated later in the week.

Please report any problems to the helpdesk.
